author: Kathaleen Roberts / Journal Staff Writer
title: ‘Aida’ pits two princesses against one another and captures the roiling emotions of rejection and disloyalty
text:
From left, Shana Blake Hill as Aida, Kristin Chavez as Amneris and Clay Hilley as Radamés form the love triangle in Verdi’s “Aida.” (Greg Sorber/Albuquerque Journal)
A love triangle set in the glory of the pyramids, “Aida” pits two princesses against one another, all for the love of an Egyptian captain.
If you go
WHAT: “Aida” by Giuseppe Verdi, presented by Opera Southwest
WHEN: 2 p.m. Oct. 25 and Nov. 1; 7:30 p.m. Oct. 28 and Oct. 30
WHERE: National Hispanic Cultural Center, 1701 Fourth SW
HOW MUCH: $15-$85. Visit operasouthwest.org or call 243-0591 or 724-4771 Verdi’s classic captures roiling emotions of rejection and disloyalty set against the tumult of war.
Opera Southwest will open its 43rd season with the tragic opera on Oct. 25 at the National Hispanic Cultural Center.
While Verdi’s score is commonly thought of as the height of grand opera, its nucleus is an intimate human drama, said Anthony Barrese, conductor and OSW artistic director. Most of the scenes feature small duets and trios, but its heart beats to a deeply personal rhythm.
It all starts as the Egyptians capture and enslave Aida, an Ethiopian princess. The Egyptian military commander Radamés struggles to choose between his love for her and his loyalty to the Pharaoh.
To complicate the plot, the Pharaoh’s daughter Amneris is in love with Radamés, but he does not return her feelings.
Stage director Brian Robertson wants to make the grand opera that is “Aida” intimate within a cast of 60.
“The great challenge of it is can we find the personal story inside the majesty?” he said in a telephone interview from Cincinnati, where he was working for the University of Cincinnati Opera Department.
Shana Blake Hill, left, portrays Aida and Clay Hilley is Radamés in the Opera Southwest production of “Aida” at the National Hispanic Cultural Center. (Greg Sorber/Albuquerque Journal)
“It has the majestical potential. But there are sections that come together with small staircases,” he said. “Each of those sections can be closed off for more intimate scenes. We’re using architecture to isolate them.”
For Albuquerque native Kirstin Chavez, the role of Amneris represents the dream of a lifetime.
“I always hoped I would be a Verdi mezzo,” she said in a telephone interview from her Dallas home. “I think now is the time.”
Chavez lived here until she was 4 years old, but spent most of her formative years in Malaysia, where her parents worked as English and music teachers.
She earned her bachelor’s of music degree from New Mexico State University. Her father gave her her first voice lesson when she was 16.
Chavez attended the Eastman School of Music, debuting at the Metropolitan Opera in 2005.
Amneris can be played as a villain; a haughty, arrogant princess. But Chavez hopes to create a more three-dimensional character.
Her character pleads with Radamés to renounce Aida; Amneris can save him from death when he is condemned for betraying his people.
Kristin Chavez portrays Amneris in the Opera Southwest’s production of “Aida” at the National Hispanic Cultural Center. (Greg Sorber/Albuquerque Journal)
“She’s a very tortured soul,” Chavez said, “and I hope to get that across.”
Tenor Clay Hilley plays the caught-in-the-middle Radamés.
“He’s a young, idealistic warrior who has his mind on one thing – his love for Aida,” Hilley said in a telephone interview from Baltimore.
But he is betrothed to Amneris.
“Of course, one never likes the pre-arranged marriage,” Hilley said. “The Pharaoh wants me to marry his daughter and be the power couple.”
Flush with Verdi’s opulent, high-altitude arias, “Aida” pitches a steep vocal climb.
“The main melody puts unaccented syllables on accented beats,” Hilley said. “You have to jump up at the end of the phrase. The aria is very exposed, (then) it fades into nothingness. Learning how to do that without resorting to falsetto is a challenge. Then you breathe a huge sigh of relief and let the diva come out.”
Familiar to Albuquerque audiences as Leila in Bizet’s “The Pearl Fishers” and Violetta in Verdi’s “La Traviata,” Shana Blake Hill is returning in the title role.
Aida and Radamés fall in love while he transports her from the battlefield to the court.
A stolen jewel, Aida is trapped between revealing herself to Radamés and concealing her identity from the Pharaoh. But she can’t reveal her gilded background for fear of becoming a pawn.
Shana Blake Hill portrays Aida in the Opera Southwest’s production of “Aida” at the National Hispanic Cultural Center. (Greg Sorber/Albuquerque Journal)
“She was like a ghost,” Hill said.
Verdi gave his leading lady her own distinctive voice.
“Her music has always got this kind of foreignness to it,” Hill said. “There’s a grace note that is almost like a flute. It’s got a mournful, far away transcendent quality. She’s always reaching out to the gods for mercy.”
But Aida is no victim, Hill maintained.
“She shows a great deal of internal fortitude and grace,” she said. “There’s this inherent, quiet nobility in her carriage.”
“Aida” is Hill’s fifth performance with Opera Southwest.
“It’s been wonderful to have an association with this company and watch it grow,” she said. “This kind of company is the future of this art form. This is a community that loves its artists.”
